in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about physical properties of sound, different aspects of electronic music such as musique concrete and DAWs.
lots about music production

I learned about the history/techniques/advancements of music technologies, some prime examples of techniques, and how to work a Digital Audio Workstation (although this wasn't really covered in class, it was more something we had to do for homework)
I learned so much about music technology & how to use/apply techniques learned in the class. I also gained a better understanding of music history.
I learned a lot about the history of music tech + some other fundamentals about concepts like reverb compression, etc.

I learned the math and physics underlying 20th century music technology, as well as the cultural history of musique concrete as it developed alongside major shifts in music technology. This course was an excellent balance of science, cultural history, musicology, and technology.

you learn a lot about the historical significance of certain musical technologies and how they've evolved into modern technologies, and there's lots of opportunities to do projects and put this knowledge to work
music software and physical knowledge.
Learned a lot about Digital Audio Workstations, which I think will be nice to know at some point again in the future.
Increased familiarity with a wide range of popular music technologies, including MIDI and DAWs, as well as new knowledge about how various technologies affected music throughout recent history.
I gained an understanding of the basic concepts concerning sound, recorded music, electronically produced music, and the technologies that make these concepts possible.

A lot of really necessary fundamentals of music technology: learning to use Max/MSP, understanding DAWs better, understanding the acoustics (physics) and computing/electronic parameters that are necessary to do work with tech. Getting familiar with the histories of electronics and technology in 20th and 21st century music.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Could have had more comprehensive notes with formulas and a better explanation of topics. The lectures felt like they could have been shorter than they were.
more clarity regarding what important during lectures would be helpful

I think this class was not what I was expecting, and that is definitely at least partially due to COVID. The lack of in person labs meant so many necessary resources were unavailable to us throughout the semester. Overall, it was lacking in this department, it was very hard to learn about a lot of the DAWs, and other concepts like MIDI without examples and without a proper lab section of this class. I want to believe that when these are available, this class would be much better but it felt very weak this semester, at no fault of the professor. The content we did learn though, the history and the examples given were always in depth and fun to learn about. Props for that.

There was so much interesting material and great ways to practice/apply what we learned. It was a bit difficult because of its virtual format, and I know it would have been even more engaging in person.
I think the slides sometimes didn't cover the PSET content, but the professor was super engaging. The lab groups were also very fun and friendly. I had a super awesome time in this class.

The strength of this course is how it sits on the intersection between STEM, the arts, and the humanities. The course traces the relationship between technological shifts in music production and subsequent musicological shifts. My biggest gripe with the course is that I would have wanted a more expansive history of modern music technology and more emphasis on the cultural history after the 1960s. Electronic, funk music, and hip-hop are all incredibly technology-dependent genres of music, and I would have liked more breadth to focus on these subjects alongside the many weeks of musique concrete we discussed. Sometimes it also felt like we were being tested on material that wasn't discussed in class or the readings, and had to search for answers online.
good class and still worked well over zoom

Strengths: Great use of demos/other modes of engagement during online lectures. 

Weaknesses: Problem Sets were poorly written, grading expectations were not made clear.
Being taught in-person would obviously help, but besides that perhaps a little less emphasis on the basic physics and more hands-on assignments,

I think it would be helpful to have some example pset problems done during lecture or in section, because otherwise it was very difficult to do the psets correctly without outside help or research. However, that was obviously not the main focus of the course, and the course was very well taught and were very informative. I learned a lot and felt my creative skills being nurtured.

The course material itself was very interesting and helpful; however, I found it less than helpful that the class was only lecture, with basically no participation from students. It seems like the course material would lend itself to a more interactive or hands-on style class, instead of the professor just doing demos all the time.
Very well organized, very thorough, very clear about the mathematical fundamentals and concepts necessary to be able to work properly in the field. I thought this course was great!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: did not have access to more advanced technologies that we wouldve had access to if we were in person. maybe looking into paying for better music software for students could improve the online version of the course

Recording was good! I wish uploading psets was more streamlined, writing everything out and then having to type everything into canvas was tedious and unnecessary in my opinion. We should just be able to scan in our psets and submit it as a pdf. Also generally, the canvas page could've been a little cleaner. I don't know why I had to go to "pages" to "weekly schedule" when all my other classes either used "modules" or had a specific "weekly schedule" on the canvas sidebar. Small things like this made the canvas page weird to navigate and tedious.
The virtual lab groups succeeded for sure. I think showing videos + doing digital demos actually made this class even better in a way since we could see all of the MAX stuff up close.
The combination of recorded lectures and live discussions groups worked very well, and the take home exams and problem sets were well facilitated to learning.
sections were tough to keep engaging
Answered in the previous question.

Again, interaction and engagement on the part of the students was almost zero due to the lecture style of the class. It seems like the course material would lend itself to a more interactive or hands-on style class, instead of the professor just doing demos all the time.

I think the course was very well adapted to the COVID-19 restrictions. Although I know it is not possible because of COVID-19, I wish there would have been more hands-on projects with the tech available at CCAM.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are in the computing and the arts music track, this is a required class. It's not too bad though.

Yes! You'll learn about the wacky/weird (and super interesting) histories behind the tools and sounds of contemporary music, as well as how they might be used (although this is very much NOT a course on music production). Konrad is also a Max/MSP wizard (and a super friendly and good-humored professor), and he puts together tons of his own cool interactive demos for each lecture. Only two downsides were that weekly two-hour 9:25am lectures on Zoom can be a drag, and labs were often not very enjoyable (despite our TA's enthusiasm, most people's cameras would remain off, lots of breakout room activities that didn't feel very engaging or helpful).
Also: if you're CPAR + Music, definitely take this course as early as you can. The material isn't super challenging, and it serves as a good introduction to ideas that you'll be encountering again in greater detail in other classes (esp. synthesis techniques/how sound works in the digital domain). I took this after taking CPSC 432 and some of Konrad's other classes, and it sometimes felt like it was covering the basics of stuff I had already learned 2 or 3 times in other classes.
yes if they want to get a better understanding of how technology had shaped music
yes. very interesting stuff and manageable

The way it was taught in the time of COVID, I would not recommend this course. I don't believe this class if meant to be taken the way it was taught this year, I felt like I've learned very little and have only become a little more familiar with DAWs. Again, I don't believe this to be at the fault of anyone, but rather the circumstances did not allow this class to be what it is meant to be. I want to believe I would recommend this class if I took it under normal circumstances, but I guess I'll never know.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in music and/or technology. Its very interesting even if you dont have a musical/technology background and even if you do know some, youre bound to learn a lot more.
Yes! I loved this class so much. If you are interested in music production definitely give this a shot!

I would recommend this to a student who has a very particular interest in music technology and the math behind it. I would not recommend this to a student in search of a Sc/QR gut, as I watched many students struggle with those concepts when set against the musical background needed for the class. Lastly, there were certain elements of musicological analysis that were difficult to parse as a non-musician in this class, so I would note that non-musicians may have to put in a little extra effort to keep up in this course.
if interested the physics and software of music
Only as a fifth credit, the material was pretty light, but it can be fun for people interested in the subject.
Absolutely. I learned a ton about how to produce music digitally as well as the history and technology behind modern music.

Yes, very much so! Dr. Kaczmarek knows so much and is very up to date with all the latest advancements in the subject. Because of that, he is very aware of what fundamentals students need to learn in order to be able to engage with the increasingly sophisticated technology.
